I've only just begun to look at using JUnit, however I have a lot of
experience with automating GUI tests.


I should introduce myself a little - I work for the Java SW Division of Sun
(or whatever the official name for Javasoft is nowadays), developing test
tools and test suites in the group that tests the "client aspects" of J2SE
(the software package previously known as "The JDK"). I had a hand in
creating the java.awt.Robot class (this email address is my personal email).


In our team we widely use Robot for GUI automation. We do, though, have
different requirements than most since we are testing the JDK as it is being
developed, rather than testing an application built using the shipping JDK.
I gave a brief talk last week at a JavaOne BOF about what we're doing for
GUI test automation.


The glance I've taken at JUnit so far tells me it's a framework to help
creating test cases, and that there's nothing in it to aid GUI automation.
We've created a few different similar frameworks in our test suites here,
and I can tell you that at the level I see JUnit operating, that use of
Robot fits in very well. Also, that if you choose to use Robot, that you
will need to develop some higher level code to provide higher level
functionality.


We have gotten a lot of mileage out of validation through looking at
internal state. Primarily this boils down to listening to listener
interfaces, and saying that the test passes if the right listeners are
called.


- David Herron



It isn't a question of being favorable or not. It is a question of "Do you
want to automate the testing of your GUI with JUnit? And if so, to what
granularity?" I think testing the GUI is always good, but there are
limitations for JUnit to do this. If there is pertinent state information
that you want to capture (which it doesn't sound like there is) you can use
the approach I mentioned before. If you simply want to test the overall
look, a one-eyed inspection is fine. If you want to programmatically test
the overall look, something like SilkTest would probably be a good way to
go. I think that having state inspectors on every GUI component is
overkill! If there is some meta-state that your controller gets from the
view to effect a change on your model, then write an inspector on your
controller for that, but not just for testing. The test should reflect (to
some degree) the usage. Again, this isn't a silver bullet, it's just one
example.

MVC can be difficult. If it is done improperly it offers many traps!! But
done rightly, it's a wonderful tool. Testing is easier, refactoring is
easier, etc.

-Jason
